content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <rdf:RDF xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns="http://purl.org/rss/1.0/" xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#"> <channel rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/2160/16"> <title>Llenyddiaeth Saesneg ac Ysgrifennu Creadigol / English & Creative Writing</title> <link>http://hdl.handle.net/2160/16</link> <description/> <items> <rdf:Seq> <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://hdl.handle.net/2160/27529"/> <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://hdl.handle.net/2160/27528"/> <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://hdl.handle.net/2160/27527"/> <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://hdl.handle.net/2160/27526"/> </rdf:Seq> </items> <dc:date>2015-03-20T04:02:49Z</dc:date> </channel> <item rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/2160/27529"> <title>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdStrange Longings\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd: Keats and Feet</title> <link>http://hdl.handle.net/2160/27529</link> <description>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdStrange Longings\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd: Keats and Feet Richard </description> <dc:date>2002-01-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/2160/27528"> <title>'Full-grown lambs': Immaturity and 'To Autumn'</title> <link>http://hdl.handle.net/2160/27528</link> <description>'Full-grown lambs': Immaturity and 'To Autumn' Richard While Keats's early publications were frequently derided by contemporary reviewers as puerile, the ode 'To Autumn' elicited generally approving comments. Indeed, the poem raised hopes in conservative quarters that Keats had, at last, 'grown up'. According to more recent critical orthodoxy, 'To Autumn' is regarded as having achieved a supreme, unimpeachable maturity. The overwhelming majority of scholarly addresses to the poem praise its poise and steadiness as it moves, resignedly, towards finality and closure. Countering such readings, I argue that 'To Autumn' actually represents one of Keats's most sustained and piercing attacks on the logic of mature power. </description> <dc:date>2002-01-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/2160/27527"> <title>John Keats, Barry Cornwall, and Leigh Hunt's Literary Pocket-Book</title> <link>http://hdl.handle.net/2160/27527</link> <description>John Keats, Barry Cornwall, and Leigh Hunt's Literary Pocket-Book Richard </description> <dc:date>2001-07-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/2160/27526"> <title>Nationalism and the Reception of Jacob Grimm's Deutsche Grammatik by English-Speaking Audiences</title> <link>http://hdl.handle.net/2160/27526</link> <description>Nationalism and the Reception of Jacob Grimm's Deutsche Grammatik by English-Speaking Audiences Richard Grimm \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdarrived\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd in Britain in the 1830s, more than a decade after his pioneering insights into the nature of language first appeared in the Deutsche Grammatik. This essay offers a comprehensive survey of Grimm's British reception to determine why, and in what ways, the German grammarian's theories permeated British-speaking consciousness at this particular historical juncture. It is especially concerned to relate Grimm to a fundamental shift that occurred in popular and scholarly perceptions of language in Britain in the 1830s and early 1840s, when the status of English changed from that of poor cousin to Latin and Greek, to equal sibling with the classical tongues. The nationalistic uses and misuses of Grimm in this process of revision will be drawn into sharp focus. </description> <dc:date>2001-07-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </item> </rdf:RDF>
